title: Gallery Talk: Signs and Wonders—The Photographs of John Beasley Greene
title_display: Gallery Talk: Signs and Wonders—The Photographs of John Beasley Greene
hero_caption: John Beasley Greene. Giza. Sphinx, 1853–54. Bibliothèque nationale de France.
short_description: Over the course of his exceptionally brief career, John Beasley Greene (1832–56) produced work in Egypt and Algeria that both helped advance archaeology and define photography in its early decades. To make sense of his landscape photographs within the archaeological and colonial context of mid-19th-century France, join Liz Siegel, curator of Photography, and Ashley Arico, Elizabeth McIlvaine Assistant Curator of Ancient Art, for this interdisciplinary tour of Signs and Wonders: The Photographs of John Beasley Greene.
description:
Over the course of his exceptionally brief career, John Beasley Greene (1832–56) produced work in Egypt and Algeria that both helped advance archaeology and define photography in its early decades. To make sense of his landscape photographs within the archaeological and colonial context of mid-19th-century France, join Liz Siegel, curator of Photography, and Ashley Arico, Elizabeth McIlvaine Assistant Curator of Ancient Art, for this interdisciplinary tour of Signs and Wonders: The Photographs of John Beasley Greene.

Please note: This tour has limited capacity. Participation will be on a first-come, first-served basis.

(Please note that the artwork on this page may not be featured during the gallery talk.)
